And on depreciation, have you changed your assumption for depreciation for the full year and what's the impact on your guidance?

So on depreciation, not really, on the amortization of intangibles and licenses, we're saying now about 8.2 billion, I think we'd indicated about 8.5 previously and that is just due to looking at the asset lives on the brand on businesses and things like that. So slightly lower level now predicted.
And that feeds into your guidance, basically 300 million feed into your guidance.
That is fed into the guidance.
Thanks.
So we are here, then to the front.

Thanks for that. Michael Armitage, Astaire Securities. Very simple question which I probably don't really expect an answer, but I'll have a go, which is Orange's pricing on the iPhone is very obviously dramatically similar to O2's pricing on the iPhone. And they seem to be making it quite difficult for pre-registered customers actually to get it until after the expiry of their current contract. So some people were actually getting quoted 2011 for delivery for their iPhone. So they don't seem to be going for share and it seems, well, I haven't actually talked to them, but I was wondering what your reaction to that is and how you, we might expect the iPhone launch to be for Vodafone?

It's – as you correctly said you don't expect me to tell you two months in advance what we will do in the UK. I have to tell you that kind of wrapping up many of the points raised, we think we have a good distribution, good network. We will play our own fair game into the iPhone market but two months ahead or whatever is the delivery date. We are collecting pre-registration and the only thing I can tell you if Orange customers are very unhappy they can go into red shops if they want.

Yeah, hi. Mandeep Singh from Berenberg. It's a question on the U.S., I mean on the one hand you talk about Verizon Wireless being 34% of operating profit. And then Andy says well, you know you sit down with them once a year and sort of discuss the dividend. I don't think that really conveys how important it is to the market in terms of ascribing appropriate value to the asset. Is it really nothing you can do with that or is it just no sit down once a year and have a friendly chat and see if they might pay you some dividends? I mean, presumably there's other things you can do with these guys, I mean, you've got the stake in Italy, I mean, how important is it to management to address this issue?

As I said at a recent conference in New York. We keep reviewing on a regular basis, all of our asset and therefore as you would expect the biggest one is being reviewed a couple of times per year at the Board. We review all the possibilities and the alternatives. The current best alternative is to just continue to cooperate. The company generates as Andy has shown a very, very hefty cash flow. For the time being the priority is to repay the dividend, to repay the debt and then we'll have the discussion on dividends. We are very open-minded to everything, but of course we have the value to our shareholders as the main priority. Back there?
It's Steve Malcolm from Evolution. Can I come back to the – the UK market, which I know is a relatively small, but possibly -
Yeah.

psychologically important. I mean, you mentioned you've done some good things in the last six months before that you'd done some very bad things. I mean, you tried to change distribution, it didn't work, you didn't get the iPhone, that was pretty catastrophic. How can you convince us that getting the iPhone just doesn't sort of accelerate the washing machine of churn once again through offering the same product? You've seen your margins go from the low 30s to low 20s. I mean can you share with us a point at which you might begin to take market share again? How you think about the trade-off between revenues and margin, where this market might go to, you've had some consolidation as well, which could be a good thing, but intuitively one looks at the iPhone coming and just thinks more competition, indirect distribution is the winner, the operators aren't. How can you change that?

Yeah, let me correct you, if you don't mind on one thing you said, we have done many bad things. I really don't believe that trying to rationalize distribution in this country was a bad decision. It was an unsuccessful decision. It was maybe, we hope that the whole market would evolve in a certain direction which has not happened. But to be honest, we have not been stuck to it and we said fine. We go back to a different type of distribution model. So I'm not so sure that you can say the decision was bad per se. The iPhone, we haven't got the iPhone in a number of markets, we have got the iPhone in other markets. At the end of the day, it's a commercial negotiation and whoever has an exclusive device or property can do what they want with it. How can I convince you? I think I would like Michel to say few words, but I think it's going to be next year. So once we have – we are on the same foot on distribution, on branding, and on products having one of, as Steve has said, one of the best, if not the best network in the country, I think it will be fair game. And so next year, three quarters from now, two quarters from now, I will have to convince you with the numbers. It's a bit like Turkey in a way. At some point, numbers will have to show that things will go in the right direction. Michel, do you want to add something?

Just to confer to what you have said, I guess that it will take a few quarters, but I think that what has been achieved in the previous months go in the right direction, branding new product offerings into prepaid arena, for example, but also in the postpaid, new devices. So of course, you are speaking about the iPhone, but I guess that the iPhone is not the only one, we'll have large array of Smartphones in the next coming weeks and months, whether it's a 360 device, whether it's BlackBerry, whether it's a Google phone, whether it's the iPhone so which means that we'll have a bunch of new devices for our customers there. We have work of course on the distribution and we start to get some traction, having in mind that we re-entered in the distribution only in July. So of course, there is ramp-up in order to get the benefit of it. We'll start to see that in the next coming months, of course, also. So I think that all the basics are now right and that should play in the next coming quarters. We should also benefit from this consolidation which is going to take place. We all know that when a consolidation occurs of course the people which are not part of this consolidation can grab some benefits of it, because we'll be more focused on our customers instead of being focused on the consolidation itself. So which means that with all that in the next coming quarters, but it will take some time. We should start to deliver an improvement of our situation in the UK.
I think we have time for one more question. Last one.

Thanks. MaryLou from Mobile News Magazine. You might not be ready to address this question yet, but in terms of a potential head count reduction to go with the new billion pound cost cutting program, do you expect this to be kind of consistent with the reductions that were made with the program that's just about to be completed or would this be different?

Our cost efficiency programs are not about head count MaryLou. As I said, many of the advantages are coming through things like purchasing more through our Vodafone Procurement Company, rationalizing more IT which by the way is already outsourced. So it's kind of a different model of work with outsourcers. It's property, it's space, there's a lot of things, logistics consolidation which of course can have some impact, but we are not talking about huge things. So it's a variety of things. And as we did in the past, we will manage it in a very, I would say, sensible way, initiative-by-initiative, project-by-project like we did in the past. So I wouldn't expect big announcements of big head count things, but a progressive consolidation work.
I think time is over. I would like to thank you all for coming. Thank you for your question and looking forward to the individual meet.
